segments.text: Do you want me to read these?
Do you want to read these?
Well, why don't we just start off with when you did come to Galveston.
Okay.
And what was the background that you came with?
All right.
I was employed by the city of Galveston in the fall of 1977.
I was hired as, I would argue, as part of a reform movement, a movement to professionalize city government in Galveston.
Prior to my being there, Galveston had not had a history of having professional planners, trained professional planners.
Only for a brief period of time, I believe in 1971, 72, somewhere around that time, did they actually have a degreed planner who was on the staff.
That person served for about one year and then left.
Galveston did have a comprehensive plan.
I believe it was prepared by Marvin Springer.
And I believe it was done sometime in the 1960s.
It was a typical kind of Springer plan.
They also had a zoning ordinance.
And I'll be happy to send you something that'll give you some specifics.
I can look up the dates on that and find out when they did it.
The plan was, of course, very outdated.
The zoning ordinance was very traditional, standard kind of ordinance.
It had been amended very infrequently
in the years since it was adopted, and I'm not sure when it was, but again, I'll look that up for you.
The city didn't do a systematic review of its plan.
That plan was quite old when I saw it.
In terms of priorities, updating the plan was not one of my priorities.
Galveston is...
basically two cities, two distinct cities.
One is the area behind the seawall, and the other is the area known as the West End or West Beach.
It's probably divided equally in two in that respect.
I think the West End is about 16 miles.
It is not behind the seawall.
It is an environmentally fragile area with dunes, very minimum topography, probably seven or eight foot maximum elevation.
a lot of wetland vegetation.
And the predominant pattern of development out there was a secondary home market with absentee ownership for the most part.
My perspective was that a traditional kind of comprehensive plan was out of place for Galveston.
The built-up part was already basically 90%, 95% urbanized.
It was an infill situation.
That was not something that dictated the need for a comprehensive plan.
What was really needed was neighborhood planning for the built-up areas, for the infilling, for revitalization.
And so I committed the department to doing neighborhood planning, although it also was not the number one priority that I had when I came.
But I recognized that it was a need.
It was something that would be very useful to us.
So I did commit to having a person on our staff that would
work in that area.
There was only one staff member in the planning department when I arrived, and that person was doing zoning administration.
Planning was under the Department of Traffic.
There was no physical planning going on of any kind, no capital improvements programming, no grant work.
It was strictly zoning and subdivision administration.
The plan that Springer had and the comprehensive plan, had that much of an effect on Yaxton?
Oh, I suspect that most of the island was developed before Springer did his plan.
And I would question whether the plan was as much of a predictor as it was as much as a recognizer of what was already there.
So it wasn't a plan that was meant to inspire.
It was a very typical, ordinary, very simple,
in a not very complex, comprehensive plan.
They're very suitable for their needs and certainly for their capabilities.
Well, again, I was hired as, again, what I would argue is part of this reform movement.
They hired their first professional city manager about six months to a year before I came.
His name was Tom Muhlenbeck.
He was a graduate from city management in the management program at Kansas University.
one of the more recognized programs in city management.
And he was committed to the professionalism of the various departments, and one of which was planning.
So I was brought in as the head of planning and traffic, and still we're leaving planning and traffic together.
But the planning was of such importance at that time, they moved me to the head of this department.
I built up a planning staff and brought in
I believe, five professional planners over the next two-year period, most of them during the first year.
Most of them were quite young.

In fact, I went to the three planning schools that I had a great deal of respect for to the University of Texas at Austin, Texas A&M, and Oklahoma University, and hired the top graduating students from each program.
I went in and asked the faculty who was number one, and that's the student I wanted, and that's who we hired.
I created a good environment.

for people to, for the students, for the new planters to use their skills that they learned in school and put them to real world usefulness right off the bat gave them a lot of responsibility, gave them authority to go with the responsibility.
We put a major emphasis on environmental planning.
There had been a complete lack of environmental planning in the history of the island.
in the urbanization that had taken place.

It was a classic case of man overcoming nature and dominating it, showing how they could force urbanization into an environmentally sensitive area and do it with a great deal of unconcern about what they were, the ecosystem they were disturbing.
We received some financial assistance from the state
and a grant to develop this, what was called the West End Ecosystem Plan.
Ray Quay was the environmental planner that I'd hired from the University of Texas at Austin, who kind of spearheaded this effort.
We hired Kent Butler from Texas A&M for a very small sum of money to do a study for us.
We worked with the Texas Marine Affairs Council.
Galveston at that time had its own Marine Affairs Council.
that the city council had appointed probably maybe a year before I came, very short lead time before I arrived on the scene that they had created that group.
Harris Kempner from the Kempner family was the head of that group and a big, strong supporter and advocate for environmental planning and for some analysis of what was happening at the port.
At that time, there was growing interest in deepening the port.
And he was concerned about what impact that would have on the environment.
Also at that time, the citizens, or the city council anyway, politicized the parking situation on West Beach.
Under Texas law, the beaches have historically been open, open to everybody, common ownership, public ownership, public access to the beaches.
Part of the problem in Galveston was that this was a very dense urban area, or certainly close proximity to a very dense urban area in the city of Houston.
And the population pressures on the beach were overwhelming.
We had unbelievable numbers of vehicles driving on the beaches.
And for example, during one three-month period in a control area of about one mile, we logged in almost 150 vehicular accidents on the beach.
Somewhere around 40 of those accidents involved pedestrians with vehicles.
And a number of those accidents involved vehicles and horses.
So it was a very unsafe, very hazardous, dangerous situation.
Apparently, there were quite a few professionals hired into the city yourself, the city manager and such.
What was the impetus to bring that about all at once in Galveston?
I know that any place politically has cycles and goes through swings.
Galveston was going through an enlightened period where they felt they needed more sophisticated government.
There was a great deal of dissatisfaction with the government.
There had historically been a great deal of dissatisfaction.
Galveston was very political.
They were one of the last cities, if not the last city in the country, to do away with electing department heads at large elections for.
You know, your planning director, your director of traffic, director of public works, police chief, fire chief.
I believe up until darn near the late 50s, if I'm correct, they were electing these department heads.
Part of that reform movement that took place then, I guess, resurfaced and was trying to professionalize local government.
And Muhlenbeck was committed to that.
The council was, for the majority, committed to doing that.
And I think the community wanted it.
So that's the impetus behind this thing.
We did professionalize.
We did bring in very competent, quality people.
We dealt with, I'll read through here, some things that we did in the two-year period from 77 to 79.
We completed this beach and dune management plan for Galveston Island that was part of the West End ecosystem plan.
That was a major component of it.
produced a West Beach access and parking plan that provided the planning basis and the ordinances for closing off the beaches to vehicular traffic.
And that became the first time in the history of Texas that any part of the beach had been closed off to vehicular traffic.
So that was very innovative, very controversial.
It got the Attorney General's office involved in it, Senator Ray Swartz with the, I can't remember what his committee was that he was with,
I held hearings on that.
We had something in Texas Monthly to the effect that what we have done is taken a precious resource away from the public.
We were denying the public access to the beaches.
In reality, we were trying to correct a very serious incompatibility problem between pedestrians and vehicles.
No city, no urban area in Texas would allow a major road to go through their park system where their kids are playing.
And that's, in essence, what that West End of the Island was.
That's a park system.
We had other problems.
It was a very complex issue.
But anyway, we did treat those.
For the first time, the planning department produced a capital improvements program.
It was the 1978-1983 capital improvements program.
It was a legitimate, true, comprehensive capital improvement program.
We established priorities.
We looked at available funding sources.
We analyzed the financing capabilities of the community.
a good citizen participation process to kind of help us in picking priorities.
The planning commission provided great leadership in developing that plan, and it was adopted by the city council.
In fact, during this two-year period of time, the planning commission was the entity providing this critical leadership that we needed to make these very important planning projects come forward.
They were strong leaders, excellent advocates,
And they were really the force behind the force.
The city council was not that aggressive, was not that supportive, very nervous as to what they were doing.
Many of the things that were done during this two-year period that I'll continue reading were done on split votes in the face of substantial opposition.
I can remember one of our proposals was to create neighborhood planning commissions.
I'm not aware of any city in Texas that has done that.
We felt it was important because of my desire to do neighborhood planning in the redevelopment areas.

We felt it was important to use neighborhood planning commissions because that was going to give us a built-in group that would help coordinate the plan and participate directly in preparing the plan for each of these neighborhoods.

We also were starting, we had the community development block grant program that was expanding and the attempt was going to be made to let the neighborhoods have a better, have more important, have a bigger role
in determining the priorities and how those funds would be spent in their neighborhoods.
The Planning Commission supported this concept 100%.
They did not see it as an infringement on their commission rules.
They were happy to share it.
They were happy to get this kind of participation.
The City Council had a tied vote on whether or not to do this.
It was three to three, with one member absent.
The member who was absent was a very strong advocate of neighborhood planning commissions.
When he returned the next week, the vote was
It failed by four to three instead of passing by four to three because the mayor, Mayor Unbehagen, changed his vote from being for it to being against it.
So it did fail four to three.
The leading advocate for defeating this movement was the city attorney, Bob Shattuck.
Bob's view was that the neighborhood planning commission
would end up usurping the authority of the city council.

It would end up putting constraints on the council because it would be very difficult for the council to use their judgment or substitute their judgment in neighborhood matters for the judgment of that neighborhood commission.
So for that, he cautioned the council that this was a weakening of their authority and their power.
And he advised them against doing that.
And he finally ended up winning the day in that area.
When I arrived in Galveston, their zoning ordinance, which was quite old, was in various folders in files.
It was not all put together.
One of the first things I did was bring it all together and put it into a one common book there where it could be kept current.
They made copies of it so the public could have access to it.
The last year, toward the last year that I was there, we developed a performance, productivity,
budgeting system.
That was something I was very strongly supportive of.

I was proposing to do something like the City of Dayton had done, where the idea was to get a sense of direction for the community, understand what we were trying to achieve on the basis of some kind of plans, and see that the budget's instruments were used as a device for implementing the plan, rather than the budget being the objective, having the budget
used as a planning device for implementing council objectives.
So I proposed going to this program performance budget.
We had a line on a very traditional, antiquated kind of budgeting system when I was there.
I didn't have much support for that.
However, after about a year, a
Backlash, I'd say a continuing backlash, because basically government had not demonstrated to the citizens of Galveston that it was responsive to them.
It was tremendous dissatisfaction.
Year in, year out, the people in the council were turned out of office.
It was just, you served one term and you were gone.
The voters were not satisfied with the services they were receiving.
Well, finally, this thing, the backlash was so substantial
that they passed a freeze, a rollback on taxes.
It was a charter amendment that, in essence, rolled back taxes and froze the taxing level and the amount of money that could be raised on taxes in any given year.
Even put libs on revenue so that we couldn't even, in theory, bring in federal grants, if you read that charter amendment with preciseness.
The manager's view was we shouldn't fight this.
We should let the citizen groups
you know, argument themselves.
So we didn't participate.
We didn't even give them information, which I thought was a mistake.

The manager's view was that he didn't want to be in a situation such as in California where the employees all said this was bad, you can't do it, and then when it passes, turn around and do it, you know, and say, well, what happened?
You said we were going to lose this and this and this.
Why didn't we?
So he didn't want to suffer from that credibility problem.
So we didn't campaign.
We didn't participate.
And this charter meeting was overwhelmingly passed.
And I believe in the first year, it was going to necessitate a 25% to 30% cut in the budget immediately right off the top.
And it was going to require additional cuts in years beyond that because of the way it was phasing in.
So in order to get a handle on the budget and how to make cuts, the manager accepted my year earlier suggestion that they go to this productivity management by objective kind of approach.
to making decisions.
And we went to a citywide survey where all the citizens in Galveston were asked to assess the various services that they were receiving.
They were asked to assess the quality of those services.
And then they were asked to indicate whether or not they favored an increase or a decrease in those services, and what was the magnitude of the decrease that they favored.
We had pretty good turnout.
I believe it was 10%, 12% of the citizens across the island that returned our survey.
That was used.
in giving guidance to the city council and selecting priorities for making the budget cuts.

So I was pleased to see us going to that system, although, of course, I was disappointed that it required the circumstance, the painful experience, the budgetary experience to make us go to that kind of system.
What's interesting about that is that that system is no longer used today.
That was retained.
I left after two years.
The manager continued that.
for about another year after I left, and then that manager left.
And the new city manager, the current city manager, Steve Huffman, does not use that budgeting system anymore.
We started the first of the neighborhood planning programs.
It was the East End Neighborhood Plan.
We surveyed the neighborhood with
mailbox and personal visits to everybody, mail cards in the mail.
We got about a 10% response to our survey.
We asked him to identify issues, problems, priorities, the typical kinds of information you need to do a neighborhood plan.
We attempted to create an advisory group without the appointed powers of the city council, without the council appointing them because that had been rejected by the council.
And we did identify issues and we prepared
position papers and had a lot of documentation for resolving those issues for at least presenting alternatives for resolution of those issues when I left.
About a year after I left, I would probably say, 80 or late 80, the first neighborhood plan was produced.
I believe now they have completed two or three other neighborhood plans in the last several years.
What's interesting about that, too, is now the current city planning director, Roger Hendrick, who replaced me, is gearing up to do a comprehensive plan.
His view is, at this point, they have a need for a comprehensive plan.
My view was that comprehensive plan wasn't needed in the built-up area.

And that it was going to be very difficult to produce a comprehensive plan for the west end of the island because its shape was so narrow and the environmental factors were so significant that I thought a performance management system was far better.
And that's what we were attempting to do with this West End Ecosystem Plan with developing these performance criteria and standards for urban development.
And I felt that was the way to go with each development being reviewed through a specific use permit or PUD kind of regulatory process, as opposed to a general plan with

specific zoning districts that would allow uses by right and standard setbacks i didn't feel there was anything in the west end of the island that allowed a standardization and uniformity with with respect to the treatment development i thought each area was uniquely different and sensitive and therefore the comprehensive planning approach would have been the wrong approach to use roger just disagrees with me on that
Is it the different opinion of two professionals, or is it more the situation of Galveston has changed and it's becoming more so appropriate for...
I think it's a difference in the professionals' views.
I think Roger and I are just different in that respect.
We have a very similar background, but...
He sincerely believes that you can do a comprehensive plan for that wisdom of the island, a meaningful plan.
And I could not get a handle on it.
I'm basically used to doing my own comprehensive plans.
And I have done a number.
And in that situation, I could not see how I would approach it.
It looked to me like it required a great deal of site-specific analysis.
And that does not lend itself to a comprehensive approach to planning.
Roger disagrees.
And what is interesting about this, though, he proposed to hire consultants to do this.
So if there's a changed circumstance there, he has money that I did not have, because we were a very poor department when I was there.
We reformed the way we did zoning reports while I was there.
I introduced a very standardized format based on the old ASPO report entitled Writing Better Zoning Reports.
It's a PAS study, a PAS report.
And it was an attempt to get
a little bit more professionalism into the zoning evaluation process.
It was very well received.
The planning commission was outstanding.
Carolyn Stiles was the chairman during the last year I was there.
Jules Love was chairman during the first year.
Carolyn Stiles may be one of the most outstanding citizen planners there ever was.
Just a very dedicated, enthusiastic individual.

very aggressive, very active, who had some political clout behind the scenes, along with some other people on our commission, and made it possible for us to do a large number of things in a very short period of time here as I'm continuing to go through.

I think if you sum up in this when I finish, you're going to see, gosh, in two years, coming in with no staff, and the one staff person that was there during the zoning administration left very shortly,
After I got there to go to law school as part of his career plans, his wife was a medical student.
He'd been planning to leave, and she graduated, and she graduated, and he left.
So we built the staff for nothing.
We had literally no materials in our offices.
We didn't have any census materials.
We had no planning publications.
Nothing relating to planning was in that planning office, not a document, except for several copies of the old comprehensive plan that
just happened to have been preserved for some reason.
We did some areas and some things with respect to the historic district.
Galveston had two historical districts that had been created in the early 70s.
Most people think of Galveston as being a classic example of historical preservation and successful efforts in historical preservation.
It's very beneficial to the economy, a significant contributor to the economy.
What's particularly interesting about it, though, is at the time I was there,
The community, in general, was not supportive of historical preservation.
And the city council was even anti-historical preservation.
The worst thing one could do at that time was to suggest something involving historical preservation.
They were completely turned off by it and sensitive to it.
I think that just had to do with the unique culture of Galveston.
Galveston is a unique place.
Every place is unique, but Galveston is definitely unique.

The attitude in the island there of the average citizen, certainly the elected officials, and I think they did a pretty good job of representing the citizens in this area, was that historical preservation was elitism, was for some kind of upper crust visitor.
They basically took it for granted.
They didn't see anything special about those buildings.
It was just a rare
combination of the right people in the right time and the right events that even made it possible for them to get that historical district established, those two districts in the early 70s.
When I attempted to expand the districts, I was completely rejected.
That was one area I could make no progress in whatsoever.
We had a landmark commission that was grappling for help, didn't know how to respond to the issues of new construction in our districts.
I was able to get a grant from the state of Texas Historical Commission, and we hired Ellen Beasley just before I left.
my second year to do a manual for guidelines for new construction that was produced about a year after I left.
That was extremely beneficial to the Landmark Commission because they did have a difficult time in assessing these new construction projects and trying to protect historical areas.
I was able to promote a historical district signage program where we posted signs up in the city letting visitors, tourists know where the districts were and also

putting in street signs in the district that were different color, uniquely different, so that the residents would know about it and anybody else who wandered through that neighborhood would know about it.
I wanted, therefore, a psychological value, an educational value, a warning value in the sense that you couldn't do anything in the historic district without permits from the city.
You couldn't paint your porch.
You couldn't replace railing.
The city had very restrictive regulations in the historic district, and people didn't know about that.
And that was always the story we were getting.

So we felt like by putting in these signs saying, here are these districts, and then changing the street signs and putting in these brown signs with special symbols on them and logos, that people would figure out there was, hey, something's going on here.
And we could use it as part of our educational campaign.
At that time, we were working with Peter Brink in the Galveston Historical Foundation.
He was the executive director.
We were working with him on the Strand and what we could do to help them in the way
traffic circulation, various kinds of grants and consultants came in.
The foundations were very interested in helping out the strand.

The Harris Foundation, the Kempners, the Moody Trust, all of these groups were very interested in doing something to encourage economic development and to preserve the kind of heritage of Galveston at the same time.
Pete Fredrickson was on our planning commission.
He was a city councilman who also served as ex-officio on our planning commission.
And he was one of the individuals who was working on restoration of the Alissa, which is a sailing ship that's in Galveston now.
And he worked very diligently with other people to bring that about, with Polly Guido and some other folks, to try to build on Galveston's unique culture and heritage.
rewarding for the staff that we had in our offices to be able to work with these kind of people, the local groups.
We did find groups with specialized interests that were extremely helpful to us, giving us technical assistance, giving us behind-the-scenes political clout.
And I have to admit, I was naive in that respect.

I really didn't know how many of the ideas I was floating, our staff was floating, that were legitimately good ideas that were winning on their own merits versus how many were being sold by these supporters and advocates for us.
But I do know that we had tremendous support from a number of very influential special interest groups.
And they were very active people.
And when I go back to Galveston today, I run into them.
And they remembered what we did during those couple of years.
And the political climate has changed.
And Roger can't do those.
The planning director at Galveston couldn't do
Very many of the things that we were able to do in the two years I was there.
I happened to be there at the right time for really being able to have significant impact.
We had an energy conservation demonstration program.
We were one of 17 cities that received a grant from the state of Texas.
We produced an energy conservation handbook designed for the East End Historic District, for our neighborhood, one of our specific neighborhoods.
There's a lot of material around on energy conservation, but we wanted something designed just for Galveston Island, just for our own geographic area.
Plus, we needed something designed for the unique kinds of housing we had on Galveston Island, especially with all the historical property that we had, the very older structures.
So we produced a very specialized document, ideally designed and trained and suited for Galveston.
We also produced a number of workshops
where we gave residents hands-on experience, got them to come in and learn how to do various things, how to make their houses more energy efficient.
It was particularly important because some of the older houses, contrary to public perception about how energy efficient these older homes are, are extremely inefficient.

So it was important to be able to show them how to make these houses more energy efficient without losing historical character, and therefore making it possible for them to afford to live in those units instead of being driven out.
We processed grants from the state, from the Coastal Energy Impact Program.
We were able to bring in several grants.
I wish I could remember what all they were.
One of them was for purchasing parkland along the west end of the island before it was developed so we'd have public access to the beaches.
Part of it was used in our parking program where we were trying to move vehicles off the beaches and put them into designated parking areas.
We did an oil and gas master plan.
At the time we were there, the drilling for oil and gas became very controversial.
Galveston did not have regulations that prohibited drilling for oil and gas on most of the island.
Parts of the built-up area were protected, but vast areas were not.
The environmentally sensitive areas were not, and offshore drilling was not regulated.
So we worked with a couple of the citizen groups that were very interested in doing this.
They had enough pressure, enough influence that they were able to make, and the council wasn't interested in this emergency,

They were able to make the council call an election to put a charter provision requiring the preparation of an oil and gas master plan and the regulation of drilling and requiring voter approval of that plan.
And we did that.
We prepared a plan.
The first plan, I'm thinking maybe the first plan did not pass.
The second plan was approved by the voters.
And we did come up with some very fine regulations.
controlling the drilling for oil and gas.
And at that time, I also served as the petroleum superintendent, in addition to being the director of planning and traffic.
The major concern or fear was that, on offshore drilling, that there might be a mishap or an accident, and that a spill might wash ashore and ruin the beaches.
And Galveston depends so heavily on beaches and tourism.
that that would have been devastating to the local economy.

So one of the provisions in our plan was to limit the seasonal drilling so that if the spill took place, it would do it at the right time of the year when prevailing winds would take it away and you'd have a chance to recover, et cetera.
So we did actually produce a plan called an oil and gas master plan.
We produced ordinances that were both approved by the voters and adopted by the city council.
We attempted to do some things in the area of beautification.
There was growing interest in that.
improving the physical appearance of the island.
There was an awareness that the island was not as pretty as it could be.
And in many respects, it's extremely degrading what has been done with urbanization, that concrete seawall.
We did come up with some beautification plans for the seawall.
Rogers continued and expanded on those beautification plans.
They involved planters.
We attempted to landscape one of the parking lanes on the seawall for some area and put some fill in dirt and grass on top of that concrete seawall in certain places.
And we worked with the Corps.
We were able to get that through the Corps and the county.
It was very difficult, but finally we were able to convince them to do that.
But I think it was probably the merchants more than anybody
that kept us from putting that landscaping in and really doing something that would have been beneficial.
Also, the traffic engineer that worked under me at that time was not supportive of these efforts and was more interested in moving traffic along the seawall than he was in beautifying it.
And he was a behind-the-scenes person who worked to stop us from doing these things.
I attempted to take truck parking off of Seawall Boulevard at that time and got some support, but when it really came down to it,
The council voted without any public discussion, voted and rejected unanimously.
So I never did understand the politics of that.
But I know there was some behind the scenes maneuvering on that.
It was a very valid concept to remove those trucks up there when they were parking on the seawall in front of restaurants and motels and hotels.
It was literally blocking off the view for hundreds and hundreds of feet.
For the people who were in the restaurants and motels and hotels and the windows who were living there, who were staying there with the idea of seeing, you know, experiencing Galveston.
All they were experiencing was the sight of a refrigerated truck or moving truck or something.
Try to establish a traffic diverter program in the neighborhoods.
Galveston has a grid system, street system.
Every street's a thoroughfare.
In particular, around the medical center.
There's a problem with all the thoroughfare streets.
And the medical center is close to the port.
So we were getting heavy truck traffic, a lot of medical center traffic, student traffic, faculty traffic through our residential neighborhoods.
And it was a serious parking problem because the university wasn't providing the parking that they should have been doing.
So I attempted to come up with a traffic diverter program where the streets would not intersect through.
There would be a diagonal divider, a landscape divider.
And you would have to make a turn to be able to move.
That is something that also failed.
On a split vote, the traffic commission was opposed to it.
We got the neighborhoods to support it.
We were going to put our first one in over by an elementary school, which would have been extremely valuable to do.
But the traffic engineer fought us tooth and nail.
He strung that out.
And I left before I was able to get that issue up to the council.
I don't believe they ever followed through with it.
I spent a lot of time educating the planning commission.
We spent good money, good to city money, sending our commissioners to conferences, to short courses, signing them up as members of the American Planning Association, seeing they got publications.
I put on a number of workshops for them.
I gave them a notebook that was prepared by me based on some materials I had previously written, plus some other
written information that other planners had done that I retyped, giving proper credit to the people that did it, put it in a notebook format, and gave it to our commissioners.
It was probably a 15-chapter notebook.
It was a handbook for planning commissioners is what it was entitled.
And it was on such things as introduction to comp, to planning, introduction to the planning commission, sign regulations,
I'm trying to remember some of the other chapters.
Gosh, this is horrible.
I'm trying to blank on this.
Introduction to the Community Development Block Grant Program.
Basic rudimentary kinds of planning information.
The principles, concepts, and standards for residential development, for commercial development.
Just basic rudimentary studies.
I tried to do for them in two years
what you would to a graduate planning student.
Of course, I didn't have near the time.
But we attempted to have a workshop at least once a month where there was no regulation, no current planning being conducted, strictly educational session, study session.
I felt it was extremely important to raise their level of knowledge and expertise.
I knew I wasn't going to be there forever.
I knew our staff, which was very young and aggressive, very confident, was not going to be there in future years.
So I wanted to leave a presence behind
a strong supporting presence for planning.
And so I put a lot of my time and energy in building up the knowledge and the capability of that planning commission.
And I think that that was probably as responsible and as much responsible for our eventual successes there in the latter year that I was there as much as anything.
The commission came alive, was excited about planning, was enthusiastic about it.
They looked forward to those workshop sessions.
They put tremendous pressure on staff
to come forward with new and aggressive and innovative ideas.
One of the subjects they brought up was the landscaping ordinance.
We talked about beautification.

We did pass landscaping orders requiring that parking lots be landscaped, requiring that peripheral boundaries be landscaped, requiring that development on certain major streets on the island be landscaped for aesthetic reasons, 100% purely aesthetics.
Very successful.

A lot of these things don't sound very significant to you, but if you'd understand that we started from zero, no support for planning, no support for regulation, very conservative kind of community, to think that you could go in there and accomplish and impose these kinds of restrictive standards and regulations and do these things in a planning area, you know, it's just astonishing to people.
At the same time, we were interested in landscaping.
was a group interested in doing something about billboard regulations.
Now, the challenge of that was that the chairman of the planning commission, Jules Love, owned the local sign company.
So the council appointed a subcommittee.
And Jules was on that subcommittee along with several other people.
And they produced a report and got it back to the commission.
And it was a good report.
It had some good recommendations.
But when it got to the commission, it had been watered down a little bit by Jules.
But when it got to the commission,

Carolyn Stiles, in particular, was able to take that and really expand it and go beyond the basic minimum regulations to something much greater than that, even taking down existing billboards and freezing the number that were there and coming up with some simplistic kinds of trade-offs.
If you want this, you take two down.
If you want this, you do something else.
And that was very successful, in my view.
It was good support for that.
We were able to do that, get those changes.

Oh, in the area of energy conservation, one of the things I forgot to mention was we instituted an energy audit program where our city staff would go out and audit houses and give people an idea of what they could do to make their houses energy efficient, give them kind of a printout.
We designed these things to give a printout to them, showing them what could be done in the order of priority that would pay for itself and what would be the payout to do that.
What's interesting about that is
We'd only been offering that about three months when the federal government passed some national legislation requiring local utility companies to offer that service.
So we were there doing something that was taken over by the local utility companies.
We did come up with some preliminary zoning performance standards for the canals, wetland areas, and drainage areas.
But we never implemented them.
We did have the standards.
We tried to make reference to them in our PUD.
in the processing of our PUD requests.
But we were never able to put those into ordinance format.
Now, after I left, I believe about a year after I left, Roger Hedrick was able to get some of these standards adopted.
And I think they do have much more, much stronger controls now than they do when I was there.
A lot of the interest and support for environmental planning no longer exists.
And Roger's not going to ever be near as effective as I was.
The planner that I'd hired right away finally left because he was so discouraged
by the change in political environment there.
And they were elected to the city to continue to see us poke our nose into the environmental areas, which didn't have that much support from the citizens.
So that's in summary what we were able to do in a very short period of time, two years.
We tried to make up for a period of 10 to 15 years of neglect in planning.
and probably one of the most productive two years in my life.
I was enthusiastic.
It was the first time that I was really a planning director where I had professional staff.
I had kind of served as a planning director in a very small city for two years while I was going to school, but never had I had the chance to be in charge
With complete freedom.
I had complete freedom.
The city manager did not dictate to me, did not direct my program efforts.
I had 100% authority to look at anything and to do anything and everything that I wanted to do.
And I had complete freedom to bring it up to the commission and the council and take the heat for it.
The council, I would say, was reluctant to pass many of the things that they did.
In summary here, they was reluctant to do it.
They were not enthusiastic supporters of planning or of regulations.
They kept being forced into it.
And I felt like our technical work was so sound.
Our logic was so good.
Our justification for it was so good.
Our press coverage was so supportive.
And not just local, but the Houston papers and the Houston news stations as well.
And then the behind-the-scenes influence that many of our commissioners and our special interest groups had in the community.
All that in combination made it a
but mean hog heaven for a planner.
It was an ideal time, a very exciting time.
I was disappointed to leave.
I left the island primarily because my wife didn't like Galveston.
She wanted to pursue her education.
Galveston has no educational opportunities for higher education, unless you want to be a medical student.
I had the chance to go to a larger community, double the size, Beaumont, Texas.
And there was a good city manager there who sold me on that.
And going to that city, too, told me that I could do in Beaumont what I did in Galveston.
And he'd be supportive of it.
And he wanted me over there.
So that kind of new challenge and the chance to make
my wife happy, I made the decision to move on over there.
I've been tempted a couple of times to go back.
I know that the current city manager was the assistant city manager when I was there.
We're very good friends, personal friends.
And Steve was a great person to work with there on the staff.
And he's talked to me a couple of times about coming back and one of these years they may end up twisting my arm and getting me back down there.
Is there any particular legislation, state and federal, that's really impacted Galveston's planning?
Well, not in the mandatory sense.
Galveston was doing things
for the right reason.
We were doing plans because they were useful, because they were needed.
And we were always, the end state wasn't the plan.
The plan was the means of giving us a strategy, the mechanism, the step-by-step approach to getting to where we wanted to go.
So Galveston did not necessarily benefit from any kind of legislation that I was ever aware of.
Secondarily, we did.
Sure, the Coastal Zone Energy Impact Program was beneficial to us.
It gave us some money to use for acquisitions, for development.
But we weren't using monies for planning purposes.
We did have some transportation planning money.
